nodes.bodyText: Do we want/need to support multiple simultaneous logins? It seems like the user may want to be authenticated to multiple Wikibases and then choose which one to use for a given operation.
Do we want to continue to support password based logins at all? I'd much prefer that we don't have access to the users' passwords unless we absolutely have to.
A Wikibase instance may don't have the OAuth extension installed, so password based logins should be supported.

By the way, MediaWiki makes it possible to create "bot passwords", which are alternative passwords for the account that also come with restricted permissions. We should encourage users to create bot passwords to use them from OpenRefine: https://addshore.com/2020/07/using-openrefine-with-wikidata-for-the-first-time/
To handle "bot passwords", do we need to change the current code?
No, it is the same API - we could just consider tweaking the UI to encourage users to create such passwords. Arguably that is a different issue, independent from this PR.

Yes, we should definitely strongly encourage this. It looks like "bot" usernames can be identified by the @ sign that they contain, so we can issue strong warning if we don't see it (and also encourage them to use OAuth if available).
I'm fine with that being a separate PR, as long as we don't lose track of it.
I've created #3108 to track this.
Does the exception include any more information about the parse error which would be useful to pass back to the user? e.g. column, character, error message, etc.
Maybe I should append e.getMessage() to the message.

Yes, that would be good. There's also org.apache.commons.lang.exception.ExceptionUtils.getFullStackTrace(e), but hopefully the stacktrace won't be necessary because the range of errors here is limited.
What are the semantics of our versioning? Can we deal with any 1.x here or only exactly 1.0?
I didn't deal with versioning well in this prototype, and I'm not sure if it's necessary to have the manifest versioned. I'll add a comment below to talk about my thinking on the versioning.

Are these Jackson annotations required? It looks like your naming scheme matches the default expected by Jackson so perhaps you don't need them. @wetneb has more experience with Jackson than I, so perhaps he can confirm.

In constructors, @JsonProperty annotations are required for all arguments. I think it is also a good practice to also annotate all getters with @JsonProperty or @JsonIgnore to make the JSON mapping explicit and make sure we are not changing it by mistake when renaming an attribute, but that's a personal taste.
OK
This field name doesn't match it's serialization. It'd probably be easier if they matched.
I'll fix this.
Could you compute this transform algorithmically to reduce the verbosity? Perhaps by using the same code that Jackson uses in SnakeCaseStrategy.translate() on an array of Class objects.
I'll give it a try.
fixed

I'm not sure I fully understand the lifecycle here, but could this be rolled into batchIsBeginning()? Because it's a new abstract method, it's a breaking change that all subclasses are going to need adapt to, so it's no worse to change the contract of batchIsBeginning to be abstract boolean, making it mandatory and returning the success indication that you need.
After more review, I'm seeing a lot of boilerplate where subclasses just return true. Should that be the default, overridable implementation here to cut down on the boilerplate or is it something that we want subclasses to explicitly think about and handle?
Under what circumstances prepareDependencies fail? What should the user do about it?
Always use braces please. They avoid subtle and hard to find indentation bugs
Got it!
The names don't match here. Are they correct? Does one of them need to be adjusted?
Sorry I don't get what you mean here.
I was wondering why lowerValueProperty wasn't the same as or aligned with differenceWithinRangeConstraintPid but I guess it's just due to the complexity of the Wikidata constraint system.
Please wrap long lines. Although style guides don't require 80 columns any more, most suggest no more than 100. We've been negligent in formalizing our style guide, so not your fault for not knowing.
Got it.
Braces
Should failures be logged or cause an error here?
I think we should log the failures here. Causing an error is no proper since missing dependencies is expected.
wrap
combine as above
Doesn't this mean that this will never get used?
This is obviously a mistake :)
Is it too late to sync up these names?
It is worth making the code and the JSON format consistent but I would advocate to keep the @JsonProperty annotations anyway.
This is a very wide throws statement. Can it be narrowed at all to a smaller subset of Exceptions?

As I mentioned by email, if we think users are going to have to deal with manifests, we may want to think about using YAML instead of JSON. In addition to be easier for humans to edit, it allows comments.
Looks like we're moving towards having manifests provided to us, so this shouldn't be as big of an issue.
In particular, we need tests for version (missing, different minor version, different major version), as well as malformed manifests.
It would be good if this didn't block the UI (but I know it's probably not your code).
Can these error messages be internationalized?
The work on checking the format of the manifest is not finished yet, I'll add i18n support when this part is done.

Thanks for letting me know that it will be addressed. I'm trying to strike a balance between commenting constantly and ignoring you. :) I'm also concerned that the PR is becoming enormous and will be completely unreviewable if I don't do it incrementally.
"Gridworks" is the name that preceded "Google Refine", which was replaced by "OpenRefine" so occurrences of "gridworks" should be globally replaced with "openrefine"
Can this be put in the Ajax completion function rather than relying on a fixed timer?
Probably don't need the extra level of package depth here (ie remove ".v1")
Not all scrutinizers rely on WikibaseQualityConstraints, so it is worth inspecting the batch even if no constraints are set up in the manifest.
Fixed with commit 4d9cc4e below.
This "Manage Wikibase" string should be localized. I would propose "Select Wikibase instance" to be more precise ("manage" is vague - I feel bad for using it in "Manage Wikibase account"…)
Configure Wikibase account?
Could be better!
async: true is the default.
Presumably this needs to be an http[s] URL. Is there any reason to leave it open ended?
Using "format": "url" and pattern": "^.*/$ solves this.
Can the colors be inherited from the main project?
Yes
You probably want to check isMissingNode() before trying to get the textValue(). Do we have a test for a malformed manifest e.g. missing a version?

I think it would be wise to validate on the backend rather than depending on the client to provide well-formed data. Generally speaking, I don't think that the backend should count on well-behaved clients.
I've created a separate issue for that (#3109), though, so we can merge this PR.
Thanks Tom.
Can the the JSON property and the getter names be aligned here?
For backward compatibility, the JSON property should be "itemDocuments". And since the type of the return value is Expression, naming the getter "getItemDocumentExpressions" makes more sense.
Sounds good.
Can the the JSON property and the getter names be aligned here?
Naming both to "siteIri" could be better.
Can we pretty print this to make it easier to diff for future edits? It's small enough that it shouldn't have a performance impact.
